input: scene: a bedroom description: A man is sitting in a playpen. He's holding some kind of communicator. uncanny: Adults don't use playpens. entities: Infant_bed, Ageing. caption: Honey? The baby's outsmarted me again.
target: It's sometimes difficult to get babies to sleep at night --- this parent was trying to make their baby sleep, but somehow, the baby tricked them into putting on the baby's pajamas and made the parent get into the crib, accomplishing the baby's goal of not sleeping. It's funny to think how intelligent the baby would need to be to pull this off. Also, based on the parent's message over the baby monitor to their partner, apparently this isn't the first time this has happened.
caption_choices: Honey? The baby's outsmarted me again.
generated_idefics: The man in the image is sitting in a rocking chair next to a crib, and it appears that he is looking at a baby who is sitting in the crib. The caption suggests that the man's wife has been telling him that their baby has been outsmarting them, and he is now looking at the baby who is in the crib.
generated_llama2: Oh, this one is a doozy! So, the man is in a playpen, which is usually a place where children play, but in this case, it's the man who's in there! And he's holding a communicator, which is a device that allows him to talk to someone remotely. But the punchline is that he's saying "Honey? The baby's outsmarted me again." Which means that the man is admitting that he's been outsmarted by his own baby! It's a play on words, as "outsmarted" can also mean "fooling around with" or "playing tricks on". So, the man is basically saying that his baby has been playing tricks on him!

input: scene: a meeting room description: An office meeting is being held in a room in a high rise. The leader is giving a speech on a microphone but the desk he and his colleagues are using is the top of a grand piano. uncanny: While a grand piano is a hard surface where many things can be done, it is never the case to actually use it as a table. entities: Piano, Board_of_directors. caption: And all because of the account that got awa-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-y ...
target: A reference to "The Man That Got Away" by Judy Garland, which is a famous pop song about a lost love that is sung with a piano accompaniment. The cartoon depicts a boss playing piano during a meeting --- and so, the popular lyric is modified by replacing "man" by "account". Instead of a lost love, the song becomes about a more benign case: a business deal that fell through. It's funny in part because the boss is not only acting a bit over-dramatic, but also, forcing his employees to listen to his signing, which isn't exactly professional.
caption_choices: And all because of the account that got awa-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-y ...
generated_idefics: The image shows a group of business people gathered around a table, and it appears that one of them has left the room abruptly. The others are discussing the reason for the person's departure, and one of them is saying that it's because of a missing account. The person who left the room is represented by a chair with a handbag on it.
generated_llama2: Oh, this one is easy! The leader is trying to say "And all because of the account that went away...", but he's standing on a piano, which is making it difficult for him to speak clearly. The "away" sound keeps getting stuck in the piano keys, making it sound like "awa-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-a-

input: scene: an office description: A woman is interviewing for a job. The one interviewing her is an angry bull. uncanny: Bulls don't work in offices. entities: Bull, Bullfighter. caption: Not so fun when you're the one being charged, is it?
target: A play on the word "charged". Generally, bulls charge towards bull fighters in the bullring, sometimes causing injury to the person. But, here the person is charging the bull in a legal sense with a lawsuit, likely related to the literal physical charging the fighter endured in the ring.
caption_choices: Not so fun when you're the one being charged, is it?
generated_idefics: The image shows a man sitting in a chair with a cow standing on top of him, and the cow is being charged by a man with a gun. The text "Not so fun when you're the one being charged, is it?" is a humorous reference to the situation the man is in, where he is the target of the cow's aggression.
generated_llama2: Ah, another classic! The bull is representing the interviewer, who is "charging" the woman with the task of impressing them for the job opening. The joke is that the woman is in a vulnerable position, as the bull is known for being aggressive and powerful, while she is just a mere mortal trying to impress them. It's a clever play on words and situations!

input: scene: an office description: Two men are standing in front of a clerk at a desk. They're holding signs that say in and out. uncanny: The signs are a little bit odd, but not exactly out of place. entities: Paper, White-collar_worker. caption: Last internship I was a coatrack.
target: A joke about bad internship jobs taken to an extreme. These two interns act doing the menial task of holding in/out paperwork, which could easily be accomplished by a simple file folder or shelf. Accordingly, another job that could be done by a human that's usually done by an inanimate object is  holding up clothes like a coatrack. It's funny to think of how bad these people's internships are, which plays on the thankless nature of real internships in the real world.
caption_choices: Last internship I was a coatrack.
generated_idefics: The image shows a man standing in front of a desk with two women, and he is holding a coat. The caption suggests that the man was previously an intern and was tasked with holding coats for the women. The man is now leaving the office, and the women are discussing his departure.
generated_llama2: Ah, another clever one! It seems like these office workers are playing a game of "Internship Charades." The two men are acting out the signs "in" and "out" to convey that they were an intern at some point, and the clerk is trying to guess which internship they're referring to. The punchline, "Last internship I was a coatrack," is a clever play on words as "coatrack" sounds like "co-track," which is a common term used in the office to refer to a coworker or colleague. So, the intern is implying that their last internship was so long ago that they've been promoted to a co-worker or colleague, rather than just a coat rack!

input: scene: rock wall description: A woman is climbing a rock climbing wall. She sees a face on the wall. uncanny: There is a face or head coming out of the rock climbing wall. entities: Human_head, Rock_climbing. caption: In retrospect, I should have been more specific when I told the genie I wanted to be in a rock group and have women climbing all over me.
target: The man was given 3 wishes by a genie and asked to be a rock star and have lots of women interested in him romantically. But, his wording of being in a "rock group" and have "women climbing on him" have secondary literal interpretations, which the genies adversarially interpreted. The "rock group" is a group of holds on a rock climbing wall, and "climbing all over me" is literally rock climbing over his head as a rock climbing hold.
caption_choices: In retrospect, I should have been more specific when I told the genie I wanted to be in a rock group and have women climbing all over me.
generated_idefics: This is a joke about a man who wished to be in a rock group and have women climbing all over him. However, the way the wish was phrased was not specific enough, and the man ended up in a situation where he is climbing a rock wall with women climbing all over him. The man is now regretting his wish and is looking back in retrospect.
generated_llama2: Oh, this one is a clever play on words! The scene described is a rock climbing wall, where a woman is climbing, and she sees a face on the wall. The joke here is that the woman is climbing a rock wall, but the face she sees is a "groupie" (a fan who follows a rock band and attends their concerts) - get it? The joke is that the woman wanted to be in a rock group (the band) and have women (groupies) climbing all over her, but instead, she's climbing a rock wall and sees a face on it! I hope that helps you understand the joke!
